title: The 2025 class of premium road cycling shoes
content:
Cyclist
The 2025 class of premium road cycling shoes

Road cycling shoes have their work cut out. They need to fit in a way that’s comfortable for long periods but also secure so there’s no foot movement.

They need to efficiently transfer the rider’s efforts into the drivetrain, which means a rock-solid sole with plenty of cleat positioning flexibility to cater to different pedal setups. They need to keep feet protected but also provide ventilation on hot days. They need to be light. And, of course, they need to look great.

A bad pair of shoes can break a ride. Conversely, a good pair can make it, which is why it’s so important to get it right. With that in mind, Cyclist has lined up nine of the best.

Our selection includes the Sidi Ergo 6, the shoe that’s spearheading a modernisation of the iconic brand, as well as the newest performance road shoes from the likes of Shimano, Trek, Giro, Scott, Canyon and Lake.

As well as the big names, we show off some models that punch above their weight in the performance stakes, such as the light and supple Ekoï Racing C12 Pro Team or Gaerne’s clean-cut G.Jet. We’re confident the lineup has something to suit all tastes and requirements, so there should be no reason why you can’t pedal in comfort this summer.

Road shoes 2025 at a glance

• Ekoï Racing C12 Pro Team
• Sidi Ergo 6
• Shimano RC703
• Gaerne G.Jet
• Trek RSL
• Lake CX333
• Giro Imperial II
• Scott Road RC Ultimate
• Canyon Tempr CFR

Ekoï Racing C12 Pro Team

£306.18, ekoi.com

As its name suggests, Ekoï’s Racing C12 Pro Team shoe has been designed with input from those at the top of the sport.

‘It is the choice of Ineos Grenadiers rider Carlos Rodríguez,’ says Alexis Rodriguez, Ekoï’s footwear lead. ‘His feedback helped us develop the shoe design, which was a three-year project.’

Alexis says the sole plate was quite literally the foundation of the shoe. It’s unique in Ekoï’s range – only used on this flagship design.

‘3K woven carbon composite, shaped to both enhance stiffness and mirror the curvature of the foot, was used to create a lightweight but rigid platform,’ says Alexis. ‘Knowing that attention to detail is key, we have inscribed a detailed grid system over the cleat mounts to ensure precise and repeatable cleat positioning.’

Where the base of the shoe is all about efficiency, the upper’s priority is comfort and security, says Alexis: ‘Unlike many competitors who opt for synthetic fabrics, we’ve used natural leather for the upper. Arranged in a wrap design as it is, where the inside half of the upper overlaps the outside half as it is tightened, the upper will enclose the foot equally, fitting like a second skin.’

An Ortholite X40 foam insole supports the upper in this regard, helping with vibration absorption and breathability.

‘That said, natural leather breathes well anyway,’ says Alexis. ‘Plus, it moulds to the rider’s feet over time, so the shoe should only get more comfortable the longer it’s worn.’

Sidi Ergo 6

£299, saddleback.co.uk

Founded in 1960, Italian brand Sidi is a pioneer in road cycling shoes, but with a recent change of management has come a new direction for its performance race shoes.

‘The new owners have come in and taken feedback from the general public, athletes and bike-fitters,’ says Sidi brand manager George Wise. ‘They already had the heritage, quality and performance, now they just needed to look at the aesthetic, the weight and the fit.’

The result is the Ergo 6, which looks radically different to the brand’s usual offerings. Its shoes have traditionally been fairly built up with panels, straps and chunky attachments. The Ergo 6, by contrast, is stripped back and refined, handmade in Italy using artisan skills to create a shoe that is understated but no less technically advanced.

‘It’s about £100 less than our Shot and Wire shoes, but the Ergo 6 is still an incredible race shoe,’ says Wise. ‘It weighs 298g; it has a new sole with a stiffness rating of 11 out of 12; it has a new micro-mesh top that’s perforated all around so breathability is excellent, and a new heel design that doesn’t have the retention system of other models, but fits snugly. It also has the new “millennium” fit, which is wider at the toe box.’

Strips of a material called Firmor act like an exoskeleton to provide more support, and Sidi claims that while the Ergo 6 is lightweight and minimalist, it is built to last, with many of its parts such as dials and heel inserts being replaceable.

‘They’re incredibly comfortable and you’ve still got that longevity,’ says Wise. ‘The Ergo 6 is a taster of what’s to come.’

Shimano RC703

£219.99, freewheel.co.uk

The RC703 may not be the top shoe in Shimano’s lineup, but it borrows many of the technologies from its pro-level (and significantly more expensive) big brother, the S-Phyre. It has also inherited a strong aesthetic resemblance.

‘The upper construction of the RC703 is almost identical to the S-Phyre RC903,’ says Tom Mott, Shimano’s soft goods brand manager. ‘However the material used on the latter remains more premium.’

In a bid to improve stability and create a direct pedal stroke sensation, the RC703 shares the low stack height and low profile of the S-Phyre as well as the adaptable fit and cable arrangement. A wraparound synthetic leather panel controls midfoot security courtesy of a side-located Boa dial, while a second lower dial modulates forefoot and toe snugness via a network of cables and a central strap.

‘We wanted to improve the shape and ventilation of the RC703, using the S-Phyre RC903 as a model,’ says Mott. ‘The shoe last is the same as the RC702 [the previous model], however the upgraded upper materials mean the fit over the top of the foot has improved.’

The more affordable price has been achieved by using single-direction Boa dials and a less premium carbon composite sole, which, alongside other variations in materials, contributes to around 20g of extra weight compared to the S-Phyre. Shimano offers a range of width and sizing options, as well as a smart sage green colourway on top of the standard black and white.

Gaerne G.Jet

£329.90, uk.gaerne.com

‘The goal with the G.Jet was to take a step forward for the top of the range, to improve the current G.Stl primarily by reducing the weight.’

So says Nicola Colonna, product marketing manager for Gaerne, and it looks like the Italian company has succeeded in its aims. The new G.Jets weigh in at an impressive 244g per shoe in a size 42, while still being supportive and stiff enough in the sole to meet the needs of Tour de France green jersey winner Biniam Girmay.

‘We gathered input from Biniam, incorporating his feedback during the brainstorming phase and subsequent development stages,’ says Colonna. ‘The upper structure, developed by Gaerne, is called G.Frametex and it provides greater foot stability and reduces the shoe’s weight thanks to the dual composite material over a reinforced chassis.’

Laser perforations in the upper help with ventilation, and an anatomical heel cup incorporates a non-slip treatment that helps to keep the rider’s foot in place when laying down the watts. The asymmetric design of the upper around the tongue ensures a close but comfortable fit, controlled by a pair of low-profile Boa Li2 dials.

The ultra-light and ultra-thin carbon sole rates 12 out of 12 on Gaerne’s own stiffness scale, ensuring the most efficient possible transfer of power from foot to pedal. What’s more, every pair of Gaerne G.Jets is made in Italy.

‘It means we can easily control the production and maintain high quality standards,’ says Colonna. ‘And above all, it ensures that the essence of the shoe remains true to our Italian heritage and passion.’

Trek RSL

£350, trekbikes.com

The RSLs were one of two pairs that spearheaded Trek’s synonymous rebrand away from Bontrager, the name that Trek’s shoes were traditionally made under. At the top of the tree is the Trek RSL Knit, which is like a highly engineered sock inside a supportive structure of straps. Far more conventional, but no less technological, is the Trek RSL, which has been designed in collaboration with the Lidl-Trek squad, home to British stars Tao Geoghegan Hart and Lizzie Deignan. The RSLs have been ridden by the team at Grand Tours and Monuments since their launch last year, and have seen frequent visits to the podium.

Trek says the RSL is its most comfortable road shoe to date, in part thanks to the MetNet relief system. This technology uses a TPU thermoplastic to offer extra stretch across the synthetic upper, providing a forgiving fit for a wider variety of foot shapes. When coupled with MetNet’s proprietary star-shaped ventilation holes, the shoe’s upper becomes more malleable and helps to eliminate hotspots and pressure points.

Elsewhere, there are four more vents on the outsole, which itself is made using the stiffest OCLV carbon plate in Trek’s arsenal. Additionally, extra heel support and a grippy non-slip lining help to secure the foot in place.

With Lidl-Trek’s powerhouse sprinter Jonathan Milan wearing and winning in the RSLs for months, there can be little doubt that the shoes are highly capable at transferring power from rider to pedals in the most efficient way possible.

Lake CX333

£395, lakecycling.com

Lake’s fleet of race-level shoes have become increasingly popular among pro riders in recent years. They have been worn by the likes of former British champions Fred Wright and Ben Swift, and Lake says it has upgraded stiffness, comfort and performance in its the latest iteration of the CX333, one of its top-tier racing shoes and Wright’s shoe of choice at Amstel Gold and other major races last year.

The CX333 – like other shoes in Lake’s lineup – can be heat-moulded in the oven to improve fit, with the exposed carbon fibre heel becoming malleable and ready to be adapted to the contours of the rider’s foot.

The design of the CX333’s upper and closure system has also been overhauled, with Lake now incorporating Carbitex CX6 arch support panels. The Carbitex material includes a carbon fibre-infused resin that conforms further to the rider’s foot over time and adds stability to the shoe’s structure.

The insole rests on top of a semi-flexible fibreglass platform that is paired with the stiff carbon outsole to provide a modulated fit. Lake says this adds some flexibility around the ball of the foot to help reduce numbness while maintaining the stiffness needed for effective power transfer.

Lake is known for its huge range of sizes and the CX333s are no different. Available in 24 sizes, three different widths and two materials – leather or vegan-friendly microfibre – all riders should be able to find a good fit.

Giro Imperial II

£399, giro.com

Perhaps the best way to understand the Imperial II, says Giro’s design manager Garrett Tollette, is to look at who rides in them.

‘Kasia Niewiadoma [Canyon-Sram-Zondacrypto] and Legion of LA’s Justin Williams wear Imperial IIs. One’s a 49kg reigning Tour de France Femmes champion, the other a 79kg criterium sprint champion – they couldn’t be more different.’

In other words, the Imperials aim to be the ultimate blend of light weight and stiffness, with a minimalist proprietary upper made of Synchwire and a high modulus sole made by carbon fibre component specialist Easton.

‘The new EC90 SLX2 sole improves stiffness by 20Nm compared to the previous Imperial’s sole, and the upper’s Synchwire construction contributes to an overall weight of just 220g per shoe,’ says Tollette.

Stiff carbon soles need no introduction, the idea being the stiffer the sole, the less energy lost between foot and crank rotation. Synchwire takes a bit more explanation.

‘It’s a stitchless material that’s vented and reinforced to create a lightweight upper with incredible airflow and integrity. It’s an advanced composite of thermo-bonded film that provides more durability and power transfer than traditional microfibre uppers.’

Add in Giro’s SuperNatural Fit Kit insoles with adjustable arch support, and dual Boa IP1 dials, and the result, says Tollette, ‘is a shoe engineered for the top step of the podium’.

Scott Road RC Ultimate

£449.99, scott-sports.com

You’ll struggle to find a more expensive pair of road shoes, but you’ll also struggle to find a pair as radical. Take the uppers of Scott’s Road RC Ultimate: the toe end is made from TPU, a lightweight thermoplastic found in many top-end shoes, but around the forefoot – a crucial area for comfort and support – Scott has found something outside cycling and well beyond the mainstream – Carbitex.

‘At the time we started to use Carbitex it was the only adaptable material with the strength of carbon fibre,’ says Scott product designer Bruno Schaller, explaining that the material, made of carbon fibres set in a flexible resin, has exceptional strength-to-weight while being able to conform – but crucially not stretch – around the foot.

‘The idea is that the most efficient shoes are the ones that hold the foot in a comfortable yet secure position, because shifting around inside a shoe means precious watts are lost before pedalling energy gets transmitted to pedals. It’s a similar story with the Ultimate’s soles.

‘They’re made from our HMX carbon fibre sandwiching a Corecell foam core, a type of polymer-based foam that adds structural support but is incredibly light,’ says Schaller. ‘Then inside the shoe is our ErgoLogic 3D pre-shaped insole with adjustable arch and metatarsal wedges, in order that the shoe can be optimised for a stable foundation for a variety of foot shapes, improving comfort and power transfer.’

Add in a pair of Boa Li2 dials and the whole package is one of the most advanced road shoes out there, thoroughly deserving of its Ultimate name.

Canyon Tempr CFR

£319.95, canyon.com

The CFR part of the Tempr CFR name stands for Canyon Factory Racing and is the title given to the German brand’s premium bikes and kit. The Tempr CFR is the company’s first foray into the road shoe market, and the result is a race-level road shoe constructed from a sock-like inner and a synthetic, perforated outer with varied levels of thickness.

‘Using zonal layering, we can design specific functionality into the various regions of the shoe,’ says Eric Horton, Canyon’s product design consultant.

Working in partnership with dial manufacturer Boa, Canyon has created the PerformFit Wrap system, which helps to disperse pressure evenly by pulling the foot both inwards and downwards courtesy of two Boa Li2 dials.

‘We have found that soft solutions are more comfortable and adapt more easily to foot shapes. This system doesn’t crush, it wraps,’ says Horton.

Also involved is insole specialist Solestar, which created a bespoke insole complete with a central metatarsal button to help relieve symptoms of hot foot and numbness.

‘We took Solestar’s CAD files for the arch contour, metatarsal bump and bottom side support structure and merged it with our specific last shape,’ says Horton.

And for maximising power transfer, the CFR shoes feature a full-length carbon plate that curves with the arch of the foot.

‘Mashing your sensitive nerves into a rigid carbon plate for hours is not necessarily what our feet were intended for,’ says Horton. ‘The contours of the full-length carbon plate mate with the supportive sock-liner and work together to provide comfort and support.’
